newsitem.title: JAPAN: Cooler weather seen hitting Japan sugar demand.
newsitem.headline: Cooler weather seen hitting Japan sugar demand.

text.p: Japan's sugar consumption in the July-September period of this year is likely to drop 1.8 percent to 576,800 tonnes from a year ago due to expected cooler-than-average weather, the Agriculture Ministry said on Friday.
It said total sugar consumption for the 1996/97 sugar year (October/September) was expected to fall 1.9 percent from a year ago to 2,331,000 tonnes.
On Thursday, Japan's Meteorological Agency predicted cooler-than-average temperatures across much of Japan for the July-September period.
"Summer weather is a key factor in determining sugar consumption, for example, sugar for juice and ice cream," said Yasuo Sasaki, deputy director of the ministry's Sugar and Starch Division.
He said demand for fructose corn syrup, used in making juice, was expected to drop by 12 percent to 185,900 tonnes in the third quarter of this year.
